title: Why don't Americans sound like the British? - Quora

response.answer_text: When you say “British”, do you mean Cockney? Glaswegian? Liverpudlian? Cardiff? Cornish? Britain has hundreds of regional accents, there is no reason to think that the USA would pick any one of them. Of course, when you say “British” you may mean “generic posh South of England” accent, and again, there is no reason why they’d adopt that either. I used to live in Wales, 10 miles from England, and the accent was distinctly different in two towns 10 miles apart. There is no such thing as the British accent, it’s hundreds of different accents, some of them barely understandable to someone not familiar with the accent. If accents can be different 10 miles away, they can sure as hell be different thousands of miles away.

The UK has many accents; the US fewer, but in part the latter’s changes pre-date the dropping of “r” by upperclass Brits in the 1800s. Scholars have a hard time figuring out what people sounded like pre-recordings since spelling (which used to be more idiosyncratic) sometimes indicated what people sounded like but not always. Comments in letters and newspapers about accents heard are not consistent. In addition black people influenced Southern English and the region of the UK could influence whether New Englanders, Mid Atlantic and Southerners sounded different. Scandinavians influenced Minnesota. There is no one reason but many. Analysis of what Shakespeare sounded like shows the US and Ireland are closer to what English used to sound like, i.e. the RP of the uppercrust in London changed more than American accents have.
